repnme.cdata!: Malawi- Second Social Action Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that development
            communication has emerged as a critical area of ensuring
            accountability and transparency. The Project demonstrated
            that in social funds, District managed public works and
            community development activities can work side by side.
            Thorough appraisal processes (extended participatory rural
            appraisals as well as desk and field appraisals) has
            contributed to the building of ownership. The provision of
            quality and timely service packages to communities requires
            better linkage between the work of the districts and central
            government officials responsible for ensuring that the
            resources are available to meet recurrent costs for
            community interventions. Malawi Social Action Fund (MASAF) I
            and II experiences with community participation has shown
            the potency of social capital as a vehicle for meeting
            economic ends, which would lead to a direct impact on
            poverty at the individual and household levels. The
            implementation of CDD program such as MASAF, where
            acquisition of goods and services for the delivery of
            sub-projects involves many actors requires that costs for
            the types of infrastructure components funded are more or
            less estimated with a greater degree of accuracy. An
            enormous amount of time by the supervision missions went
            into mutual learning and team building for capacity building
            as evidenced by the issues covered under the Aide Memoires.

            NUTRITION PROGRAM,TF040737-MALAWI: COMMUNITY DRIVEN HIV AIDS,TF040990-MALAWI: SECOND SOCIAL ACTION FUND,TF050417-NTF:ESSD-MALAWI POVERTY
            ALLEVIATION AND SUSTAINABILITY

abstracts.cdata!:
Until last year, students at Njewa
            community day secondary school in Lilongwe, the capital of
            Malawi, attended classes for only three hours a day. To
            address these, the Malawi government several years ago
            established the Malawi social action fund (MASAF), a
            facility backed by the World Bank. Due to this initiative,
            the people of Njewa send their children to a new secondary
            day school. Since its inception in 1995, MASAF has funded
            4,697 classrooms throughout Malawi. It also has supported
            the drilling of fresh water bore holes, the construction of
            community health centers, and the establishment of new
            markets across Malawi.

repnme.cdata!: Malawi - Second Social Action Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Action Fund Project
            for Malawi aims to a) address the need for socio-economic
            infrastructure development in rural and urban areas; b)
            support safety net programs by creating temporary employment
            for the very poor and financing initiatives to assist the
            most vulnerable groups such as orphans, street children,
            persons with disabilities, the aged and those affected by
            Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS); and c) enhance
            in-country capacity to identify, prioritize, and implement
            projects by training stakeholders. There are five main
            components. The first, Community Subprojects, finances
            demand-driven community-based socio-economic infrastructure
            projects, social mobilization and capacity building,
            beneficiary targeting, and project monitoring and
            evaluation. The second component, Public Works, finances
            labor-intensive works as a safety net scheme, and includes
            information, education, and communication (IEC) activities.
            The third component sponsors subprojects to construct and
            rehabilitate facilities and provide services (including
            transportation, care, etc.) to benefit vulnerable, and
            includes IEC activities that focus on sensitization and
            clarification. The fourth component, capacity enhancement,
            strengthens the capacity of the Management Unit and supports
            capacity building for all other stakeholders involved in
            implementing subprojects. The fifth component finances
            incremental operating costs.
